content: The Act titled "Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000" allows income averaging for fishermen. The Act "Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000" amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow income averaging for fishing businesses. The Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow income averaging for fishing businesses. The definition of a fishing business is expanded to include commercial fishing as defined in the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. The Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000 expands the definition of fishing businesses to include commercial fishing as defined in the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. Additionally, a new section is added to the Internal Revenue Code providing a credit for the purchase of fishing safety equipment. The Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000 expands the definition of fishing businesses to include commercial fishing as defined in the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. A new section in the Internal Revenue Code offers a credit for eligible taxpayers who incur qualified fishing safety equipment expenses, limited to 75% of expenses up to $1,500 for the taxable year. Eligible taxpayers are those engaged in a fishing business. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code provides a tax credit for eligible taxpayers engaged in a fishing business for qualified fishing safety equipment expenses, limited to $1,500 for the taxable year. The term 'qualified fishing safety equipment expenses' refers to expenses for lifesaving equipment required for a fishing business. Special rules apply, similar to section 52, including aggregation rules for multiple persons. The section discusses rules for vessels under title 46, US Code, including aggregation rules for employers. It also states that no double benefit deduction is allowed for expenses related to the credit under this section. The employer under specific sections shall be treated as one person for tax purposes. No double benefit deduction is allowed for expenses related to the credit under this section, and the basis of equipment is adjusted if a credit is allowed. Carryback limitations apply under the Internal Revenue Code. The basis of equipment is adjusted if a credit is allowed under this section. Carryback limitations apply to the fishing safety equipment credit under the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to prevent the carryback of the fishing safety equipment credit before the effective date of the enactment of section 45D. Additionally, there are conforming amendments to the general business credit section. The fishing safety equipment credit cannot be carried back to a taxable year before the enactment of section 45D. Conforming amendments are made to the general business credit section. The fishing safety equipment credit under section 45D is amended to include a new paragraph regarding the credit determination. Additionally, equipment eligible for the credit is specified in section 1016 of the Code. The fishing safety equipment credit under section 45D is amended to include a new paragraph regarding the credit determination, with equipment eligibility specified in section 1016 of the Code. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this Act apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000.
